content.webTitle: Letters: Goths, clubs and community pubs

fields.headline: Goths, clubs and community pubs
fields.bodyText: I am surprised no one has suggested adopting the Gothenburg system to save English pubs (In praise of… community pubs, 11 August). The Perthshire village where I grew up has one of the few surviving Goths. As scottishmining.co.uk explains: "The Gothenburg or Trust Public House movement originated as an attempt to control the consumption of alcohol in the Swedish city of Gothenburg. In 1855 a law was passed in Sweden making distillation of spirits at home illegal and the authorities in Gothenburg decided to award the retail spirits licences to a single company run as a trust. This trust aimed to control pubs and off licences in a way which would not encourage excessive consumption of spirits. 5% of the profit of the trusts went to the shareholders with the remainder being used to benefit the local community. In Scotland, the system was adopted mainly in mining communities of Fife and the Lothians." Catriona Graham Edinburgh • An entire editorial on community pubs without any mention of that great monument to Victorian self-help, the working men's club? Despite a buffeting in recent years, they can be found is most towns catering, as they have always done, to the needs of the community. They have a duty to try to provide some educational activity, even if this is only the provision of books and newspapers. While the beer is generally cheaper than pubs, the club of which I am a member has also gained international renown for consuming half of the UK's total imports of Bénédictine. Joe Cummings (Life member, Burnley Miners' Club) St Médard de Mussidan, France
